article_title: Workforce Boulder County taps Skyline kids to design website 'from youth, for youth'
article_text:
From left: Skyline High School seniors Tim Finnegan, Lauren Jury, Seth Hovestol and Josie Lamp, working with CU grad student Rachel Strobel as their mentor, have developed a website for kids called "Jump into Jobs." ( Lewis Geyer / Longmont Times-Call )

Workforce Boulder County has commissioned a website geared toward young people that it hopes will become a template for other Workforce centers around the state to use.

Her Skyline High School peers who helped her develop the website credit senior Josie Lamp with coming up with its name, Jump Into Jobs, and its tagline, "From Youth For Youth."

Lamp, plus Tim Finnegan, Seth Hovestol and Lauren Jury, were the four main seniors who started working on the project last year. They say they were totally unfamiliar with Workforce Boulder County before they started the project.

"It was kind of like, 'This is what Workforce does, we want a platform for youth,'" said Finnegan.

"It was actually pretty vague, which is why we signed on," added Jury.

The idea for the site goes back almost two years, according to Jane Banz, work force manager for Workforce Boulder County.

"It started with (executive director) Tom (Miller) talking about what young people do today," said Ganz. "From that, we tried to brainstorm, 'How could we get in touch with these kids?'"

Workforce posted an advertisement for an internship and through it, got connected with the University of Colorado-Boulder's Alliance for Technology, Learning and Society — or ATLAS — program. Grad student Rachel Strobel, a participant in the program, was tapped as project coordinator.

Through Skyline STEM teacher Richard Gunther they found the students to build the website.

"This was a group that I knew and I always wanted them to pilot things like this," he said.

"They came into the project the second semester their junior year," said Strobel. "So I've worked with them for a year and a half."

Initially the students thought about creating an app but then decided against it.

"Eventually we came to the idea of a website because we were focused on underprivileged youth, and we thought they might not have the money to have a smart phone," said Jury.

"Plus we wanted to put a lot of content on there," added Finnegan.

"Jump Into Jobs" website http://jumpintojobs.wfbc.org/

The four started with developing basic themes for the website, such as color schemes, and then began adding content.

Most, but not all, of the content was taken from Workforce Boulder County's site, Lamp said, but they tried to reword it to speak to a younger audience.

For example, there's this tip on what to do before a job interview:

"Get moral support. The day or night before, hang out with a positive pal, who will keep your mind off of the interview and your nerves, and give you the upbeat and helpful support you need. No Negative Nancys need to be adding to your stress or nervousness.

"The day of the interview, put away your notes and take a quiet moment just to breathe and relax yourself. Picture you walking into the interview and nailing it perfectly. Be confident in you and your abilities. You are going to rock this! Don't stress!"

They also inserted "quizlets" after much of the instructional material so the reader can test their own comprehension. Jury pushed for tying the site to social media outlets such as Pinterest and YouTube.

"I have so many friends that come up to me and say, 'I have a job interview. What shall I wear?'" Jury said. Now, she said, she can simply direct people to the Workforce Boulder County Pinterest page, where they'll find a board called "What Should I Wear?!", containing photos of appropriate interview attire.

Now that the four seniors are set to graduate it will be up to a new batch of students to take over working on the website this fall. Gunther said it's been interesting to watch the outgoing seniors interviewing students aspiring to take over next year.

"The next wave of kids will have different skill sets," said Strobel, who will also be moving on.

Added Ganz, "The second part of this project is we want to have our youth case manager work with the new group at Skyline to produce interactive content."

The four graduating students, who say they've been working together since they were freshman, feel like they've left a solid foundation for the next group of students to build upon.

"This isn't our first website but it's our best website," Finnegan said.

Ganz said that ultimately, she would like to see Jump Into Jobs website become a tool useful to youths all over the state.

"In the future we would be looking at coordinating with other Workforce regions, so they could have their own project or contribute to our project," she said.
